coredata.dc:title: Exploring the mechanism of ZrO2 structure features on H2O2 activation in Zr–Fe bimetallic catalyst
coredata.dc:creator: Yin, Yue
Lv, Ruolin
Li, Xiaoyang
Lv, Lu
Zhang, Weiming
coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic Fenton catalyst has attracted widespread attention in refractory organics removal. Herein, we firstly investigated the influence of ZrO2 structure features on H2O2 activation in Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst. The results show that the heterojunction structure will be formed after high temperature calcination, which makes the ability of Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst to activate H2O2 for bisphenol A degradation is 3.1 times higher than that of α-Fe2O3 without Zr doping. Through characterization and density functional theory, it was identified that compared to (1 1 0) interface, the adsorption energy of H2O2 on iron sites at (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) interface reduced by 1.27 kJ mol−1, while the Fe–O bond length in the stable configuration of Fe-OOH increased by 0.16 Å, which was beneficial to the association and dissociation of H2O2 on iron sites. Besides, the surface -OH of amorphous ZrO2 in Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst synthesized under low temperature conditions could promote HO2 •/O2 •- formation through the surface electron transfer, accelerating the Fe(III) reduction. In conclusion, this study reveals the influence of environment-friendly ZrO2 structure features on H2O2 activation, proposes a new insight into strengthening the synergistic effect between bimetals, and provides a reference for the structural optimization of bimetallic catalysts.

Zr–Fe bimetallic catalyst
Heterojunction
Hydroxyl

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Difference in H2O2 activation by the catalysts
Effect of ZrO2 structure on heterogeneous Fenton processes

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) XRD patterns of these catalysts; TEM images of (b) a-Zr-Fe and (c) c-Zr-Fe (white represents the crystal plane of Fe2O3, yellow represents the crystal plane of ZrO2); (d) diagram of two heterojunctions in c-Zr-Fe.
Pseudo-first-order rate constant for BPA degradation of the catalysts at different pH values. (Catalyst dosage = 0.5 g L−1, [H2O2]0 = 10 mM, [BPA]0 = 0.1 mM).
(a) UV–vis adsorption spectra of monoformazan at 530 nm in these systems; EPR spectra for (b) DMPO-HO2 •/O2 •- and (c) DMPO-HO• adducts in these systems.
(a) TGA and (b) FTIR spectra of the catalysts.
Mössbauer spectra for (a) a-Fe, (b) c-Fe, (c) a-Zr-Fe and (d) c-Zr-Fe (red represents sextet, yellow represents Doublet-1, green represents Doublet-2).
XPS spectra for Fe 2p orbits in a-Fe, c-Fe, a-Zr–Fe and c-Zr–Fe, respectively.

(a) Adsorption energies of H2O2 at (1 0 4), (1 1 0), (1 0 4)-(0 0 1) and (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) interfaces; (b) Fe–O bond lengths between iron and H2O2 at the (1 0 4), (1 1 0), (1 0 4)-(0 0 1) and (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) interfaces.
Degradation efficiency of BPA in a-Zr–Fe and c-Zr–Fe systems in reuse experiments. (Catalyst dosage = 0.5 g L−1, [H2O2]0 = 10 mM, [BPA]0 = 0.1 mM, pH = 4.0 ± 0.1).

head.ce:title: Exploring the mechanism of ZrO2 structure features on H2O2 activation in Zr–Fe bimetallic catalyst

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Pollution Control and Resource Reuse, School of the Environment, Nanjing University

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Bimetallic Fenton catalyst has attracted widespread attention in refractory organics removal. Herein, we firstly investigated the influence of ZrO2 structure features on H2O2 activation in Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst. The results show that the heterojunction structure will be formed after high temperature calcination, which makes the ability of Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst to activate H2O2 for bisphenol A degradation is 3.1 times higher than that of α-Fe2O3 without Zr doping. Through characterization and density functional theory, it was identified that compared to (1 1 0) interface, the adsorption energy of H2O2 on iron sites at (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) interface reduced by 1.27 kJ mol−1, while the Fe–O bond length in the stable configuration of Fe-OOH increased by 0.16 Å, which was beneficial to the association and dissociation of H2O2 on iron sites. Besides, the surface -OH of amorphous ZrO2 in Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst synthesized under low temperature conditions could promote HO2 •/O2 •- formation through the surface electron transfer, accelerating the Fe(III) reduction. In conclusion, this study reveals the influence of environment-friendly ZrO2 structure features on H2O2 activation, proposes a new insight into strengthening the synergistic effect between bimetals, and provides a reference for the structural optimization of bimetallic catalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: Hydroxyl radicals (HO•) with high oxidation ability (E0 = 2.73 V) and strong electrophilic addition properties, are one of the most powerful oxidizing agents, which have a significant effect on the removal of refractory organics in wastewater treatment [1–3]. Activation of H2O2 by transition metals is an effective way to generate HO• [4–6]. Among them, the Fenton reaction catalyzed by Fe(II) is considered to be the most economical and effective choice for HO• generation [7–9]. However, the traditional Fenton process still faces bottlenecks, such as narrow working pH range and secondary pollution caused by iron sludge, which need to be further improved [10–12]. In recent years, a large number of researches have been devoted to the development of heterogeneous Fenton processes. But, the cycling rate between Fe(II) and Fe(III) (k = 0.02 M−1 s−1) in the Haber-Weiss process is much lower than that of Fe(II) and H2O2 (k = 76 M−1 s−1), which still limits the generation of HO• [13,14].

The bimetallic catalytic system can realize the rapid Fe(III) reduction by coordinating the spontaneous electron transfer process inside the catalyst, without external energy supply [15,16]. In addition to the activation of H2O2 by low valence transition metals such as Cu(I), Co(I) and Mn(II), the thermodynamic spontaneous process based on the energy difference between redox potentials can also accelerate Fe(III) reduction, thus promoting the formation of HO• in the bimetallic catalysts systems [17,18]. However, the dissolution of heavy metals in this type of bimetallic catalysts can reach several milligrams per liter [19–21]. And this will not only threaten the safety of water quality, but also increase the cost of subsequent treatment.

Good biocompatibility and stability of zirconium make it can be used in the synthesis of environment-friendly bimetallic catalysts [22]. Since Zr does not possess the characteristics of variable valence state similar to Cu, Mn and Co etc., which has unsaturated 3d orbital, ZrO2 is only used as a stable carrier to enhance the dispersion of iron oxides in heterogeneous Fenton processes [23,24]. The dispersing effect and low dissolution rate of ZrO2 enable the Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst to efficiently activate H2O2 while avoiding the problem of secondary pollution caused by the dissolution of heavy metals [25]. Nevertheless, Zr with fully occupied 3d orbital may also realize the rapid electron transfer inside the catalyst through d0 surface electron transfer process [26]. Besides, direct electron supply can also achieve the reduction of H2O2, thereby generating active oxygen species [27,28]. It is inferred that Zr might be able to activate H2O2 through the surface electron transfer.

To our knowledge, the activation of H2O2 is an interface reaction on the iron site in heterogeneous Fenton processes [29,30]. And the density functional theory (DFT) calculations show that the interface energies at different crystal planes of iron oxide are different [31,32]. It means that the association of H2O2 on the iron surface will be affected by the exposed crystal faces of the catalyst. But there are few basic researches on the structure features of Zr-Fe bimetallic catalysts. Therefore, the synergistic effect between Zr-Fe bimetals has not been fully understood.

Herein, amorphous-ZrO2 (a-ZrO2) and monoclinic-ZrO2 (c-ZrO2) were prepared and used as the components of Zr-Fe bimetals to explore the different structure features of zirconium oxides in heterogeneous Fenton processes. This study reveals the relationship between Zr-Fe bimetals structure features and H2O2 activation, and provides a new insight into strengthening the synergistic effect between bimetals. In addition, ZrO2 has a stable structure, and zirconium, as an environment-friendly metal, can also effectively avoid potential secondary pollution, which further expands the application of heterogeneous Fenton catalysts in the field of environment remediation.

Unless otherwise specified, all chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade without further purification. Ferric chloride (FeCl3), zirconium chloride (ZrCl4), bisphenol A (BPA), terephthalic acid (TA), etc. were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. And H2O2 (30 wt%) were obtained from Sinopharm chemical regent Co., Ltd. All experimental solutions and suspensions were prepared in ultrapure deionized water (18.25 MΩ cm).

Solutions of FeCl3 (1.0 mol L−1, 10 mL) and ZrCl4 (1.0 mol L−1, X mL, X = 1, 2, 5) were mixed, and then heated at 60°C for 30 min. The solution was dropped into 50 mL of 3.0 mol L−1 NH4OH solution located in an ultrasound bath operating with a power of 160 W at 60 °C. After 30 min for the reaction, the solution cooled to room temperature, and the generated nanoparticles were collected by centrifugation, washed with DI water to neutral pH. The obtained ZrO2–Fe2O3 was named as a-Zr–Fe. And different Zr contents (7.5, 15.3 and 31.7 wt%) in a-Zr-Fe were also prepared. Among the catalysts with different Zr content, 31.7 Zr wt% of a-Zr-Fe exhibits the highest H2O2 activation efficiency (Fig. S1), so it was selected to conduct subsequent experiments. The obtained a-Zr–Fe was then calcined at 60°C for 2 h under flowing argon atmosphere, followed by cooling to room temperature under the argon gas. And the calcined ZrO2–Fe2O3 was named as c-Zr-Fe. Control samples a-Zr, c-Zr, a-Fe and c-Fe (α-Fe2O3) were also prepared and used in the subsequent experiments.

The structure and composition of the catalysts were analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2OOCX), X-ray diffraction (XRD, X'TRA), thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, Pyris 1 DSC), Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Nicolet iS5), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5000), and Mössbauer spectroscopy (MS-1104Em), respectively.

The typical experimental condition was included 0.5 g L−1 catalysts, 10 mM H2O2, and 0.1 mM BPA in brown flasks with magnetic stirring. And 2.0 mL aliquots were collected by 0.22 µm polyethersulfone filter at specified time intervals and quenched by 0.5 M NaNO2 for later analysis. Detailed instrument conditions are given in Supporting Information.

Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) were used to detected HO• and superoxide radicals (HO2 •/O2 •-). 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO, 100 mM) were added into water and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solution (V(water): V(DMSO) = 1: 9) for HO• and HO2 •/O2 •- detection respectively [33,34]. All EPR experimental conditions were same as the typical Fenton-like reactions mentioned above without BPA.

Excessive terephthalic acid (TA, 20 mM) was selected as a probe to quantify the generation of HO• [35]. The amount of HO• is represented by the formation of 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid (2-HTA) which is the stable hydroxylated product of TA. And the generation of O2 •- was semi-quantitative by nitro blue tetrazolium (NBT) method.

All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [36]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) [37] pseudopotential with the PBE [38] generalized gradient approximation (GGA) exchange correlation function was utilized in the computations. All energetics of metal oxides were calculated using the DFT with the Hubbard-U framework (DFT+U) to account for strongly localized d-electrons for Fe. The Hubbard-U correction terms were at Ueff(Fe) = 5.3 eV as obtained via linear response theory [39]. The cutoff energy of the plane waves basis set was 500 eV and a Monkhorst-Pack mesh of 3 × 3 × 1 was used in K‐sampling in. All structures were spin polarized and all atoms were fully relaxed with the energy convergence tolerance of 10−5 eV per atom, and the final force on each atom was < 0.01 eV Å−1.

As can be seen from high resolution TEM images, the pristine amorphous ZrO2 (a-Zr) presents a stacked block morphology, while the monoclinic ZrO2 (c-Zr) obtained after calcination is particle of about 10–20 nm (Fig. S2). The calcined iron oxide nanoparticles are mainly α-Fe2O3 (c-Fe) ( Fig. 1a), and the long-range order of the particle structure has been improved. This is mainly caused by the rearrangement of atoms in the crystal structure induced by high temperature [40]. On the other hand, amorphous ZrO2 is supported on the surface of Fe2O3. The doping of Zr changes part of the Fe-O coordination form during the iron oxides crystallization. And the difference of Fe orientation force in different coordination forms of Fe-O bond causes the (1 0 4) crystal plane to be significantly weakened, but the (1 1 0) crystal plane is strengthened [41] (Fig. 1b). After calcination, the crystal structure of c-Zr-Fe has been further improved, and the diffraction of (1 1 0) and (1 0 4) planes are obviously enhanced (Fig. 1c). Moreover, due to the recrystallization process caused by high temperature, two heterojunction regions are found at the interface of Fe2O3 (1 1 0) and ZrO2 (1 0 0) planes, Fe2O3 (1 0 4) and ZrO2 (0 0 1) planes, respectively (Figs. 1c and 1d). But the angle between the Fe2O3 (1 1 0) and ZrO2 (0 0 1) planes in a-Zr-Fe is about 73°, which leads to lattice mismatch and would not form a stable heterojunction structure [42]. Therefore, it is demonstrated that high temperature calcination could improve the crystal structure of the catalyst, and promote the heterojunctions formation between the bimetal oxides.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Difference in H2O2 activation by the catalysts

ce:section.ce:para:
The ability of the catalyst to activate H2O2 was evaluated by the degradation of model pollutant BPA. First of all, it can be seen from Fig. S3 that the removal of BPA was almost unaffected by the adsorption of these catalysts. And the rate appearing to be pseudo-first-order rate constant (k obs) to BPA degradation under different conditions as described in ln([BPA]t/[BPA]0) = -k
obs t ( Fig. 2). In the pH range of 4–8, the k obs of BPA in both a-Zr and c-Zr systems were lower than 0.001 min−1, which indicates that neither a-Zr nor c-Zr can directly activate H2O2 to degrade BPA. While BPA was degraded in a-Fe, c-Fe, a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe systems. The removal efficiency reached the maximum at pH 4.0 ± 0.1 in these systems. This was mainly because as the pH increases, stable Fe(OH)3 was formed on the surface of the catalyst, passivated the Fe sites [3], and higher pH will also cause the ineffective decomposition of H2O2 to further inhibit the Haber-Weiss cycle [7]. It is worth noting that the doping of Zr can significantly enhance the degradation of BPA. Moreover, compared with the iron oxides synthesized under the same temperature conditions, the k obs for BPA degradation in the a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe systems increased by 2.6 and 3.1 times, respectively. And the BPA degradation in a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe systems reached 90.0% and 92.8% within 60 min. These results suggest that although ZrO2 cannot directly catalyze H2O2 to degrade BPA, it would strengthen the H2O2 activation by iron oxides. And the difference in the structure features of ZrO2 were also affect the degradation efficiency of BPA.

As depict in Fig. 2, the k obs for BPA degradation in a-Zr-Fe system is always higher than that in c-Zr-Fe system. In order to distinguish the difference in the performance of H2O2 activated by catalysts, we quantitatively analyzed the active species in the two systems. Superoxide dismutase (SOD, 10 mg L−1) [43] and tert butyl alcohol (TBA, 0.1 M) [44] were used to quench HO2 •/O2 •- and HO•. It can be seen from Fig. S4 that the addition of SOD can effectively quench the HO2 •/O2 •- in the system, and the degradation rates of BPA in a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe systems are reduced by 20.8% and 13.9% at pH 4.0 ± 0.1, respectively. While the addition of TBA almost completely inhibited the degradation of BPA in these processes. This manifests that the active species in the two systems are mainly reactive oxygen species, and HO• play a major role in BPA degradation.

NBT was selected as a semiquantitative indicator of HO2 •/O2 •-, as it could react with HO2 •/O2 •- (k = 5.88 × 104 M−1 s−1) and transformed to monoformazan [45]. The results show that there were a large number of HO2 •/O2 •- formed in a-Zr system, but no obvious signal was detected in the c-Zr system ( Fig. 3a). And the amount of HO2 •/O2 •- formed in the a-Zr-Fe system was significantly increased after Zr doping. Additionally, the formation of HO2 •/O2 •- and HO• was semi-quantitatively estimated by EPR analysis by using DMPO as the trap agent (Figs. 3b and 3c). The hyperfine splitting constants (HFSC) of DMPO radical adducts were aN = 14.1 G, aH = 11.2 G (DMPO-HO2 •/O2 •-) and aN = aH = 14.2 G (DMPO-HO•). The DMPO-HO2 •/O2 •- signal in a-Zr-Fe system was 2.1 times higher than that in c-Zr-Fe system, which was close to the result of SOD quenching experiments. Furthermore, the characteristic quartet peaks of 1: 2: 2: 1 for DMPO-HO• were found to be evident. There were 251.67 ± 31.0 and 261.76 ± 18.0 μM 2-HTA detected in a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe systems, which corresponds to the steady state concentration of HO• at pH 4.0 ± 0.1 (Fig. S5). And the intensity of the DMPO-HO• signal in the c-Zr-Fe system echoed the results obtained by the TA probe. Moreover, the decomposition rate of H2O2 in the c-Zr-Fe system reached 0.053 min−1, which was much higher than that of 0.041 min−1 in the a-Zr-Fe system (Fig. S6). It means that although a large amount of HO2 •/O2 •- was generated in the a-Zr-Fe system, the amount of HO• generated in the c-Zr-Fe system was still higher than that in the a-Zr-Fe system. And the mechanism of ZrO2 structure features on the enhancement of Fe-activated H2O2 performance was different.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of ZrO2 structure on heterogeneous Fenton processes

ce:section.ce:para: Amorphous ZrO2 cannot activate H2O2 to generate HO•, but this process would generate a large amount of HO2 •/O2 •- in the system (Fig. 3). The hydroxyl groups on the surface of some transition metal oxides may activate H2O2 through the surface electron transfer process to generate HO2 •/O2 •-. As the results shown in TGA spectra ( Fig. 4a), the a-Zr was completely dehydrated after 114°C. When the temperature continues to rise to 205°C, the surface-bound -OH was completely removed (Fig. S7) [46]. This part of bound -OH accounts for about 7.6% of the total weight of the a-Zr. And the content of bound -OH on a-Fe and a-Zr-Fe was 1.9% and 2.7%, respectively. Besides, the peaks detected at 3198, 3176 and 3200 cm−1 were assigned to the surface bound -OH of a-Zr, a-Fe and a-Zr-Fe, respectively. This indicates that there was a large amount of bound -OH on the surface of amorphous ZrO2 and Fe2O3 synthesized under low temperature. In order to further identify the role of -OH in the process of H2O2 activation, 100 mM phosphate was used to substitute for -OH on the surface of metal oxides in aqueous solution. The results show that the formation of monoformazan was obviously suppressed after -OH substituted, which means that the surface -OH plays a positive role in promoting HO2 •/O2 •- formation (Fig. S8). During this process, Zr-OH could form Zr-HO2 through the surface electron transfer process with H2O2, and further dissociate to form HO2 •/O2 •-. Furthermore, the surface of the amorphous ZrO2 was hydrated to form bound -OH, which enables it to continuously activate H2O2. This explains why more monoformazan were detected in the amorphous metal oxides systems (Fig. 3a).

Compared with c-Zr-Fe, more HO2 •/O2 •- were generated in the a-Zr-Fe system. But there was more HO• detected in the c-Zr-Fe system. It means that besides the surface hydroxyl groups, other structural features of the Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst will also affect H2O2 activation. Thus, the difference in the chemical environment of iron in the catalysts before and after calcination was then analyzed. The 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of the a-Fe, c-Fe, a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe revealed prominent sextets which corresponds to the six-coordinated iron site in α-Fe2O3 ( Fig. 5) [47]. And the proportion of sextets of c-Fe and c-Zr-Fe increased to 89.4% and 86.4% after calcination ( Table 1), indicating that high temperature improves the crystallinity of the catalysts, which is consistent with XRD patterns. In addition to six-coordinated iron sites, low-coordination configurations were also detected in these catalysts. The low-coordination configurations correspond to two doublets respectively [48]. Doublet-1 represents the five-coordinated iron site, and Doublet-2 represents the four-coordinated iron site. After calcined, isomer shift (I.S.) of Doublet-1 and Doublet-2 in c-Fe increased by 0.10 mm s−1 and 0.13 mm s−1 (Figs. 5a and 5b), and the binding energies of the corresponding Fe(II) and Fe(III) in Fe 2p orbits decrease by 0.35 eV and 0.60 eV, respectively ( Fig. 6). The lower binding energy is conducive to the single electron transfer process between iron and H2O2 [49]. Moreover, the binding energy of Fe 2p orbital valence electrons in a-Zr-Fe and c-Zr-Fe was lower than that in a-Fe and c-Fe which prepared under the same temperature. This manifests that the doping of Zr could increase the charge density around Fe in the bimetallic catalyst. On the other hand, compared to a-Zr–Fe the I.S. of the five-coordinated iron site in c-Zr–Fe was increased by 0.10 mm s−1, while the I.S. of the four-coordinated iron site was decreased by 0.03 mm s−1. This may be due to the introduction of Zr and formation of heterojunctions during the high-temperature recrystallization process, resulting in the uneven distribution of surface charge on four-coordinated iron site (Fig. S9) [50]. As can be seen from Fig. 5c and d, the quadrupole splitting (Q.S.) of Doublet-2 decreased from 7.9 mm s−1 to 1.06 mm s−1 after calcination. This further illustrates that the formation of heterojunction in c-Zr-Fe may affect the process of Fe activation of H2O2.

The activation of H2O2 by iron requires the adsorption of H2O2 on iron sites [51,52]. And the adsorption energies of H2O2 at different crystal planes are quite different [53]. Therefore, we further evaluated the adsorption energy of H2O2 on iron sites at different interfaces. The adsorption energy of H2O2 (∆Gads) can be computed using the following equation [54]:
(1)

Where ∆Eb is the binding energy (kJ mol−1), ∆EZPE is the zero-point energy change (kJ mol−1), T is temperature (K) and ∆S is the entropy change (kJ mol−1 K−1). In this work, the values of ∆EZPE and ∆S were obtained by vibration frequency calculation. And the results are shown in Fig. 7a. The H2O2 adsorption energy ∆Gads = 1.33 kJ mol−1 at the Fe2O3 (1 0 4) plane indicates that the Fe2O3 (1 0 4) plane was not conducive to the adsorption of H2O2. However, after Zr doping, the H2O2 adsorption energy of the Fe2O3 (1 0 4) and ZrO2 (0 0 1) crystal planes was reduced to − 1.21 kJ mol−1, which shows that the doping of Zr can promote H2O2 adsorption on the iron sites. Moreover, the adsorption energy of H2O2 at the crystal planes of Fe2O3 (1 1 0) and ZrO2 (1 0 0) was only − 1.59 kJ mol−1, and it means that compared to other interfaces, the (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) heterojunction was more conducive to the H2O2 adsorption on the iron sites. On the other hand, the Fe-O bond lengths between iron and H2O2 at the (1 0 4), (1 1 0), (1 0 4)-(0 0 1) and (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) interfaces were 2.07, 2.12, 2.22 and 2.28 Å respectively in the steady state. And the longer Fe–O bond is beneficial to the dissociation of H2O2, which manifests that the Fe–O bond at the (1 1 0)-(1 0 0) interface was easier to break compared to other interfaces [55]. Therefore, comparing the association and dissociation process of H2O2 at these crystal planes, it is found that the heterojunction structure of Fe2O3 (1 1 0) and ZrO2 (1 0 0) was more conducive to the activation of H2O2 at the iron site, and this is also consistent with the experimental results.

After high temperature calcination, the catalytic performance and structural stability of the catalyst were obviously strengthened. In the process of reuse experiments, the BPA degradation rate in c-Zr-Fe system was always maintained above 89% ( Fig. 8). And the degradation kinetic rate of BPA in c-Zr-Fe system was significantly higher than that in a-Zr-Fe system in the later period of reuse experiments. On the other hand, the dissolution of Zr in both a-Zr–Fe and c-Zr–Fe systems was less than 150 μg L−1, but the dissolution of iron in a-Zr-Fe system was at least 149.7 μg L−1 higher than that in c-Zr–Fe system (Fig. S10). It is demonstrated that the calcinated environment-friendly Zr-Fe bimetallic catalyst c-Zr–Fe exhibits better structural stability during the heterogeneous Fenton processes. Moreover, compared with the existing Zr–Fe catalyst, it exhibits better pollutant removal performance (Table S1).

In view of the secondary pollution caused by the dissolution of heavy metals during H2O2 activation by traditional bimetallic catalysts, we prepared an environment-friendly Zr–Fe bimetallic catalyst in this work. However, the mechanism of the effect of Zr–Fe bimetal structure on H2O2 activation is still ambiguous. Therefore, the influence of the structure features of ZrO2 on the activation of H2O2 by Fe2O3 was also explored in this work. The surface hydroxyl of the amorphous ZrO2 in the Zr–Fe bimetallic catalyst synthesized under low temperature can promote the HO2 •/O2 •- formation, thereby accelerating the reduction of Fe(III). After high temperature calcination, the hydroxyl on the surface of the catalyst was removed, and heterojunction structure will be formed at the interface of Fe2O3 and ZrO2. By comparing the adsorption energy of H2O2 at the interface of different crystal planes and heterojunctions, it was found that the iron sites at the interface of Fe2O3 (1 1 0) and ZrO2 (1 0 0) planes show the strongest H2O2 activation ability. And more importantly, the catalyst stability was enhanced simultaneously after high temperature calcination, and the problem of secondary pollution of heavy metals was also alleviated. The study of the relationship between the structure and performance of Zr–Fe bimetallic catalyst proposes a new insight into strengthening the synergistic effect between bimetals. And these conclusions provide a reference for guiding the synthesis of environment-friendly bimetallic catalysts and its application in wastewater treatment.

Yue Yin: Conceptualization, Investigation, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft & editing. Ruolin Lv: Investigation, Methodology. Xiaoyang Li: Formal analysis. Lu Lv: Investigation. Weiming Zhang: Conceptualization, Supervision, Resources, Validation, Writing – review & editing.
